title: Wednesday, 27th March 2019
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Morning, then. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc.

Soundbuy Morning
OnYourRight Morning all
VV75 morning
BE11:05am

We're in the 378th circle of Brexit hell, of course, ahead of tonight's multiple choice vote.

Tony Scott morning all
BE11:06am

And if you want Brexit grey please say. I'm happy to cut and paste it so long as I don't have to read it.

FATDAZ Morning all
11:06 am

First, though, perhaps we could start with a comprehension test.

BE11:08am

Here are two sentences:

BE11:08am

1. "The review did not identify inaccuracies with material impact on the financial reports of Acme Corporation"

11:08 am
BE11:08am

and 2. "The independent review had no findings of roundtripping or corruption".

DJ Morning
Airborne Cigar I understand who it's about...
Viking1 Morning allI note the former Swedish PM suggests the krone to convert to the Euro ....
GBKrona Hola
DJ @BE I made a mistake yesterday. He didn't buy at 22p in the last 12 months, it was simply a conversion of a CFD position into actual shares so MA didn't have to make the 22p bid
DogDay morning all
BE11:10am

Does sentence one mean, "The review found that inaccuracies did not have material impact on Acme Corporation's financial reports"; or does it mean "The review did not identify inaccuracies that Acme Corporation sees as having a material impact"?

LisboaExpat olaa, morning all
BE11:10am

In other words, is the "material impact" a statement in the review or is it the opinion of Acme Corporation?

Soundbuy Brain ache..............
Airborne Cigar I suggest sentence one implies "this is without prejudice as to whether or not inaccuracies were found."
GBKrona @BE - I would have thought the first one
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Next, does sentence two mean, "The independent review found no roundtripping or corruption" .....

BE11:11am

.... or does it mean "The independent review did not reach a conclusion on whether there was roundtripping or corruption" .....

Tom Dalgleish In that context, 1
wayneJ Does the materiality clause apply in accounting for fraud?

"findings" has a specific legalese meaning that is not simply "found".

Bluesky21 Whereas Goal just suspended their shares today.

Excel Developer any quarter end risk?

wayneJ Furthermore - isn't the issue whether regulators and / or investigative authorities consider materiality in the context of the requirement of frank, open and honest disclosure to the regulator......and does that impact the risk of local licenses? Ie is the issue material in the context of the local business to the local regulator?

https://www.ft.com...-9c76-bf4a0ce37d49

Airborne Cigar Having seen an environment where reconciliation differences in the Financials DW were journaled for first and, possibly, investigated later, this seems a bit theoretical...
BE11:19am

Renault aims to restart merger talks with Nissan within 12 months and then acquire another carmaker, with Fiat Chrysler among the preferred targets, according to several people familiar with the French company’s plans.

The planning marks a new strategy following the arrest in Tokyo of Carlos Ghosn, former chief executive of Renault and chairman of Nissan, in November for financial misconduct. He denies all charges.

Both the French and Japanese sides have said publicly that their focus is on making the alliance work well before rejigging the capital structure.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Renault up 3%-ish live, leading the sector higher.

wayneJ And would a local regulator take on board if there is a risk of criminal behaviour?
BE11:20am

And we have French government on the tape saying the Renault-Nissan Alliance is an "absolute priority" for the state

wayneJ Incidentally - if ACME Corporation has commissioned an independent legal review which finds suspicion of criminal behaviour is ACME obliged to disclose the full report to the investigative authorities? ie does client - attorney privilege apply to a corporate that is regulated?
BE11:21am

.... while not commenting specifically on the report, but saying there's a board meeting scheduled for April 11.

wayneJ And if ACME is listed - and has claimed in previous investor relations statements that its staff have been cleared - does that now require a re-statement (and perhaps the local market regulator ought to investigate that)?
11:22 am
BE11:23am

So it seems we have a definite chance of a Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi-Fiat-Chrysler national champion conglomerate.

BE11:23am

Though perhaps not for a while. Here's UBS.

Excel Developer Bored with ACME
Tony Scott @BE- Surely that would be monopolistic and the regulators would be all over it?
fortyeight End of the ICE age(Internal Combustion Engine)
BE11:23am

Our base case as regards to a change in the alliance structure between Renault and Nissan is no change with a 6-12 month view. The key reasons behind this are that (1) Nissan has yet to elect a new Chairman (we only know today that Renault Chairman will be vice-chairman) and stabilise its management structure and (2) Nissan's current focus is on improving its operations (North America, in particular). FCA would bring (1) strong US exposure and (2) attractive South American exposure that could accelerate the margin improvement of Renault in the region. FCA would benefit from the alliance's early investments in electric cars.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

(@Tony: dunno, but I'm not sure the market shares would be problematic.)

wayneJ The market assumption is Renualt - Nissan first then add Fiat - but why not Exor buy part of R-N first; and then all of them merger over time?
undefined
BE11:26am

Meanwhile, over in the world of corporate, there's very very little.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

I mean, I guess there's Debs .....

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 3.44, up 1.24 (+56.42%), High: 4.24, Low: 3.10, Volume: 118.74m
Curious wasn't VW investing heavily in an electric platform to build a wide range of models on? all these brands together with one common platform would surely be good?

... coming back a bit post the initial spike to less than a penny off Sports Direct's highly potential bid.

nightingale20201 morning all
11:27 am

The upshot of which, in case you missed the RNS, is that shareholders other than Sports Direct might get 5p apiece.

On the condition that Ashley becomes CEO and the CVA/cash call is abandoned.

Shinshin Can you imagine the board meetings at FRCNM, and actually getting anything done ?
BE11:30am

What I'd expect next from Debs is a something highlighting that indicative potential bids with conditions such as "your rescue plan is wrong and I have a magic box" tend to be a tad disruptive to a business. In areas such as credit insurance, for one.

J Chisholm Hi Bryce, anything on the RDI Reit bid. Shares well below mooted offer?
Soundbuy Increasing his stake in Game too.......man's on a mission.....
PBateman GVC up ~6% on an LTIP award and comment 'We have had an excellent start to the year' and 'I remain totally committed to GVC for the long-term, and as such I will not sell any further shares in GVC while I am CEO'
11:31 am
BE11:31am

And while 5p for equity holders might catch the attention of us types, the equity holders are nearly irrelevant in the conversation here.

Forester Board meetings at Sport Direct must be fun......but you have to able to handle your ale!
DJ @BE agree, lenders are in control of the process, as always
BE11:31am

Hey! Jefferies still covers!

Viking1 What happened to Ashley going for LK Bennett?
BE11:32am

Some may see Sports Direct's possible offer for Debenhams as inevitable (once the Takeover Panel's 6 month restriction was lifted). Mike Ashley has been trying to take control and install himself as CEO in a myriad of ways - by offering loans, offering to buy subsidiary Magasin du Nord, and by requesting the removal of all Board directors (except CFO Rachel Osborne). Overleaf we detail all the twists and turns in the saga of Mike Ashley versus Debenhams.

BornCynic "The review did not identify inaccuracies with material impact on the financial reports of Acme Corporation" as a former auditor "material" generally allowed the audit partner to say to the client - meh, that mistake can go through, the accounts are still OK.
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Remaining Debenhams shareholders are stuck between a proverbial rock and a hard place - they can take a risk on Mike Ashley and a possible 5p cash offer - or put pressure on Debenhams' Board to come up with a refinancing plan that does not involve wiping out the equity. SDI's possible offer of £61m equity value (plus assistance towards immediate funding requirements) does not seem much for an estimated c.£2.2bn of sales and c.£330m of EBITDAR in FY19E. Based on estimated cal 19 EBITDA of £100m and FY18 net debt of £321m, we estimate a 5p offer would value Debenhams at 0.2x cal 19 EV/Sales and 3.8x cal 19 EV/EBITDA. Including c.£230m of lease costs, capitalised at 8x, a 5p offer would value Debenhams at 1.0x cal 19 EV incl capitalised leases Sales and 6.7x cal 19 EV incl leases EBITDAR.

BE11:32am

Strategically, Ashley will likely merge House of Fraser with Debenhams and try to extract considerable buying synergies and cost savings, in part through discussions with landlords (which may still involve a CVA). Ashley thinks the government should incentivise customers back onto the high street by taxing online retailers. We disagree and believe Debenhams needs to adapt as quickly as possible to lower rents & rates and maximise online sales. The Board must now decide whether to meet Sports Direct's pre-conditions (to install Mike Ashley immediately as CEO and terminate the current noteholder consent solicitation, due by 5pm tomorrow) and hope an offer that they can recommend to shareholders is forthcoming, or not, and continue with the c.£200m refinancing and subsequent company restructuring. Whilst the Board might err towards the latter option (given their rebuffals so far) they have said they will consider an offer and shareholders may push the Board towards an agreement.

BE11:33am

Soundbuy Fevertree- bit of fizz after yesterday's results +6.2%...........been higher.....
DJ @BE Lol how can they have a 20p upside scenario?
A. M. Quite the range there.
11:34 am

Yeah, one point to make here is that Debs equity is now being transferred to the same people who punt on binary options.

undefined
Grouchmonkey Morning. Mercifully seem to have missed Brexit and Debs.
MonkeyTrader Just worth remembering that Sports Direct in calling the EGM to get Mike Ashley on the Board actually screwed up the request by not realising their shareholding was held on swap. Had to refile the request two weeks later. Not sure they could figure out much else at this point.
11:39 am
BE11:39am

What else? Jamie Chisholm mentions this RDI Reit bid.

BE11:39am

Unsolicited from Cromwell Property Group

BE11:40am

At an indicative price of 185p.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Vs a live price of 143p, which is a pretty deep discount.

BornCynic @wayneJ - I'm way out of date on all of this and no expert. I suspect that it would all depend on the relationship between the client and the audit partner.
Grouchmonkey Berenberg must be pleased - didn't they tip RDIReit a few weeks ago as a "new consumer economy" play?
BE11:42am

Now, to recap the RDI story, it's a shopping centre operator with a lot of trapped cash and covenant risk.

BE11:42am

Peel Hunt can catch us up with this from February.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Retail headwinds. Despite well-publicised headwinds, retail occupancy remains
high at c96%. There has been a small reduction in gross annualised rent on the
centres while a number of lettings across the retail parks portfolio have helped
mitigate the impact of CVAs. That said, RDI acknowledges the “pressure” on
valuations. Thankfully the hard work undertaken over the past two years helps
lessen some of this impact, with retail exposure down to 30% from 35% via the
rotation into growth sectors, and LTV down seven percentage points to c46%.
Cash flows retained in Aviva facility. The long-term and non-recourse Aviva
facility (£144.7m outstanding at 5.5%, maturing in 2042) is secured against four
of RDI’s six shopping centres. An increase in the lender’s LTV now means that
all net operating cash flows are being retained and are expected to be used to
reduce the balance. This amounts to c£6.5m per annum, or c12% of FY18
earnings. We believe this is an isolated case, with no issues on other borrowings.
Operationally robust. The trading update reflects on six months of busy leasing,
with 100 lease events completed, delivering premiums against both previous
passing rents and ERVs. London serviced offices are “trading ahead of
expectations” and a planning application has been submitted at Charing Cross
Road to increase the lettable area by c50%. At Bicester, “healthy levels of
interest” are reported on the forward funded distribution units due to complete
in 2019.
What next? RDI has the right to cure any covenant breach in the Aviva facility
through part prepayment or additional collateral, and the Board will “carefully
consider the merits” of doing so if required. Other options could include writing
off the equity in the centres, or negotiating a satisfactory outcome with Aviva.
We estimate that, at FY18, RDI’s equity was c£50m, or c13p per share.
Revised forecasts. We reduce our adjusted earnings forecast by c8% to 13.3p,
reflecting a combination of higher finance costs (January refinancing) and lower
rental income (FY18 disposals). In addition, given £6.5m of cash is now
“trapped”, our DPS forecast for FY19 falls by more, down 30% to 9.8p. An
update will be provided at the interim results in April.
Valuation. Shares yield 6.5% on our revised FY19 dividend, and sit at a 28%
discount to our NAV forecast. Were the equity to be written off, the c15p (c7%)
reduction in NAV would narrow the discount by c5%.

BE11:43am

They have a 211.1p 2019 NAV, down from 213.8p in 2018, but given the discounts Intu and the like trade on we can probably ignore that.

undefined
Tax Realist Where does the indicative 185p come from? Can't see it in the releases or am i blind?
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian What a beautiful country to live in when someone as wonderful as Mike Ashley owns all the high-street.
BornCynic One example that I remember was the Finance Director of a company asking that a payment of £300k to a retiring directors pension not be disclosed in the accounts because the union might get hold of it. The partner said "fine". I asked if he did not want to check it out with the technical help line. The answer was "nah".

wayneJ @BornCynic - that is interesting. What would be your reaction if the CEO had had a conference call saying that an investigation had found the allegations to be 'unfounded' and then a few weeks later the company put out a statement that some employees were facing criminal investigation?@BornCynic - fair point - but materially correct accounts does not mean that there has not been a material breach of processes - which for a regulated entity is an 'issue'
11:50 am
BE11:51am

All of which is fascinating, but it's the vets work that probably has the most interest.

Tom Dalgleish unfortunate metaphor there BE
BE11:51am

Restructuring of 55 FO underperforming practices over 2H19 & FY20 (12% of the 471 total practices): These 55 practices represent the majority of the drag on Vet Group performance. Of these 55 practices, c.30 significantly underperforming practices are expected to be closed, with c.25 practices brought in-house.

A new FO JV model and reduction in fee income: In FY20, new practices are expected to be offered a reduced fee income structure to assist them in their development to maturity.

A reduction in FO near- & long-term practice rollout: Although c.20 new practices are expected in FY19, the near-term rollout plans are to be reduced to c.10 practices per year, with the long-term vet target lowered back to 700 (from an increase to 1,000 in the September 2017 CMD).

Tom Dalgleish PETS, deck chairs, Titanic?
BE11:52am

Seem to remember we talked repeatedly here about rapid vets expansion meaning opening in unprofitable locations without any economy-of-scale benefits.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

............ which are surprisingly weak for vets chains anyway.

BornCynic @WayneJ - my opinion is worthless. Out of date etc. All that I would do is to avoid the shares of the company that you describe.
BE11:54am

If Pets can identify the right vets to close, and can do so with reasonably little grief while accepting the hit of writing off the supporting loans, then sure. Maybe.

PBateman @1st let, he owns the dross on the high street
PBateman I would not let that get you down
BE11:55am

Bit of a challenge though, for a business that hasn't since flotation demonstrated much in the way of rising to challenges.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Back to the top though.

BE11:55am

Viable path towards Vet Group maturity

Management has articulated a viable plan to turn around the Vet Group (supported by a detailed 3rd party review). Although structural issues remain, we believe these are relatively well understood by investors and that a combination of management focus, market dynamics and supporting company initiatives will drive Vet Group maturity and growth. We forecast strong EBIT growth (+14% CAGR FY18-21e) and a longer-term FCF opportunity (c.6x current levels).

Sustainable growth in Retail

We argue top-line Retail performance is sustainable over the longer term (+4% CAGR FY18-21e), supported by a strong defensive market, high market share in key categories and a differentiated customer offering. Although risks to gross margin remain from branded goods pricing vs online (c.245bp), we believe Pets at Home's price architecture, brand authority to drive higher private-label penetration and premium pricing weighted towards more discretionary categories can mitigate further significant Retail margin dilution (forecast -50bps from FY19e-FY21e). We see SG&A cost inflation below group top-line growth, driving operating leverage over the medium term.

High FCF generation on stable margins

We forecast FY19e underlying PBT of £83.4m, -1.4% yoy (results on the 22 May, see inside for detailed forecasts). Across outer years, we estimate underlying EPS CAGR of +3.0% for FY19-21e driven by Revenue CAGR of +3.7%, with slight declines in gross margin (-50bps from FY19-21e) largely offset by cost leverage. Importantly we forecast robust FCF CAGR of +27% to 2021e (+12% underlying), which underpins a dividend yield of 4.8%.

Upgrade to Buy, target price 180p

Given these factors, we upgrade to Buy. We apply a SOTP valuation using a 10x FY21E EV/EBIT on Retail and an 11.5x FY21E EV/EBIT on the Vets business to derive our 180p TP (up from 136p)

BE11:55am

That's that.
